language_info.description: Complete beginner level focusing on survival Dutch

content.text: Welkom! In this lesson, you'll learn how to meet people in a Dutch park ('het park'). We'll cover greetings, introductions, and basic questions.

data.tip: The 'a' is short and open, like the 'a' in 'car', but quicker.

content.title: Subject Pronoun: ik
content.explanation: 'Ik' means 'I'. It's always used when you are talking about yourself.

content.title: Verb: heten (to be called)
content.explanation: To say your name, you use 'heten'. For 'ik', the form is 'heet'. For example: 'Ik heet Maria.'

content.title: Verb: zijn (to be)
content.explanation: To say who you are, you use 'zijn'. For 'ik', the form is 'ben'. For example: 'Ik ben Maria.' Both 'Ik heet' and 'Ik ben' can be used for your name.

content.title: Subject Pronouns: jij / je
content.explanation: 'Jij' means 'you' (informal). 'Je' is a shorter, unstressed version that is very common in spoken Dutch.

data.tip: The 'ij' sound is unique to Dutch. It sounds very similar to the 'ay' in 'say' or 'way'.

content.title: Wh- Questions
content.explanation: Questions that ask for information often start with a question word like 'Waar' (Where) or 'Hoe' (How). The verb comes right after the question word.

content.title: A Simple Greeting
content.setting: You are sitting on a bench in the park. Someone sits down nearby and says hello.

user_goal.title: Say hello and tell them your name.
user_goal.prompt: Hallo. Ik heet David.

extract_info.user_name: Extract the user's name from their message.

user_goal.title: Say 'Nice to meet you' back.
user_goal.prompt: Aangenaam, {user_name}!

user_goal.title: Ask what their name is.
user_goal.prompt: Ik heet David. Leuk je te ontmoeten.

content.title: Subject Pronoun: u
content.explanation: 'U' is the formal version of 'you'. You use it to show respect, for example when talking to older people or in formal situations.

content.text: When in doubt between 'je' and 'u', using 'u' is always the safer, more polite option.

content.title: Verb: komen (to come)
content.explanation: To say where you are from, you use 'komen'. Conjugations: 'ik kom', 'jij komt', 'u komt'.

content.title: Word Order: Verb-Second
content.explanation: In most Dutch sentences, the conjugated verb is the second element. For example: Ik (1) kom (2) uit Canada.

data.tip: The 'ui' sound is tricky. It's similar to the 'ou' in the English word 'loud', but you round your lips more.

content.title: Yes/No Questions
content.explanation: To make a simple yes/no question, you move the verb to the first position. For example: 'Je spreekt Engels.' becomes 'Spreek je Engels?'

content.title: Subject Pronouns: hij, zij/ze
content.explanation: 'Hij' means 'he'. 'Zij' means 'she'. Just like 'jij/je', 'zij' has a common unstressed form: 'ze'.

content.title: Verb Conjugation for hij/zij
content.explanation: For 'hij' and 'zij', you usually add a '-t' to the verb stem. For example: 'hij komt', 'zij spreekt', 'hij heet'.

content.title: Subject Pronouns: Plural
content.explanation: wij/we (we), jullie (you, plural), zij/ze (they).

content.title: Plural Verb Conjugation
content.explanation: For 'wij', 'jullie', and 'zij', the verb form is the same as the infinitive (the full verb). For example: 'wij komen', 'zij heten'.

data.tip: The 'z' sound is soft, like the 'z' in 'lazy'. Don't pronounce it like an 's'.

content.title: Getting to Know Someone
content.setting: You're continuing your conversation with David in the park. He asks you a question.

user_goal.title: Tell David where you come from.
user_goal.prompt: Leuk! En jij, {user_name}? Waar kom jij vandaan?

user_goal.title: Answer his question with 'Yes' and state that you speak English.
user_goal.prompt: Interessant! Spreek je Engels?

user_goal.title: Say goodbye to David.
user_goal.prompt: Oké, super! Ik ga nu wandelen in het park. Tot ziens!

content.text: Welkom! This lesson will help you talk about your home ('thuis'), family, and share contact information in Dutch.

content.title: Possessive Adjective: mijn
content.explanation: 'Mijn' means 'my'. You place it before a noun. For example: 'mijn huis' (my house).

data.tip: The 'e' is short and sharp, like in the English word 'bet'.

content.title: Possessive Adjectives: jouw & zijn/haar
content.explanation: 'Jouw' means 'your' (informal). 'Zijn' means 'his', and 'haar' means 'her'. For example: 'jouw moeder', 'zijn broer', 'haar huis'.

content.title: Possessive Adjective: uw
content.explanation: 'Uw' is the formal version of 'your'. You use it when you would use 'u'. For example: 'Wat is uw naam?'

content.text: Notice there is no accent on 'een' when it means 'a' or 'an'. 'Eén' with accents means the number one.

content.title: Talking About Family
content.setting: You are having coffee with a new Dutch friend, Sanne. She asks about your family.

user_goal.title: Answer yes, you have a brother.
user_goal.prompt: Leuk om je beter te leren kennen! Heb jij een broer?

user_goal.title: Tell her your brother's name.
user_goal.prompt: Oh, leuk! Hoe heet jouw broer?

extract_info.brother_name: Extract the brother's name from the user's message.

user_goal.title: Ask if she has a mother.
user_goal.prompt: Oké, {brother_name} is een mooie naam. Mijn broer heet Thomas.

content.title: Numbers: 0-10
content.explanation: 0 nul, 1 een, 2 twee, 3 drie, 4 vier, 5 vijf, 6 zes, 7 zeven, 8 acht, 9 negen, 10 tien.

data.tip: The 'v' sound at the beginning is soft, almost like an 'f'. The 'ij' sound is like 'ay' in 'say'.

content.title: Numbers: 11-20
content.explanation: 11 elf, 12 twaalf, 13 dertien, 14 veertien, 15 vijftien, 16 zestien, 17 zeventien, 18 achttien, 19 negentien, 20 twintig.

content.title: Numbers: 21-100
content.explanation: Above 20, the Dutch say the unit first, then 'en' (and), then the ten. For example: 21 is 'eenentwintig' (one-and-twenty).

content.text: You can often just say 'Ik ben dertig' and leave out 'jaar oud', just like in English.

content.title: Plurals
content.explanation: The most common way to make a noun plural is by adding '-en' or '-s'. For example, 'de straat' becomes 'de straten'.

content.title: Possessive Adjectives: ons/onze & jullie/hun
content.explanation: 'ons/onze' (our), 'jullie' (your, plural), 'hun' (their). 'Onze' is used for 'de'-words (onze tafel), and 'ons' for 'het'-words (ons huis).

content.title: Making Plans
content.setting: You want to exchange contact details with your new friend Sanne to meet up again.

user_goal.title: Ask for her phone number.
user_goal.prompt: Ik vind het gezellig! Zullen we een keer afspreken?

user_goal.title: Tell her your phone number is 12345.
user_goal.prompt: Ja, leuk! Mijn telefoonnummer is 06 87654321. Wat is jouw nummer?

user_goal.title: Answer her question with your age.
user_goal.prompt: Oké, ik heb je nummer: {user_phone}. Nog een vraagje, hoe oud ben je?

user_goal.title: Tell her your address is Hoofdstraat 10.
user_goal.prompt: Leuk! Ik ben 28. Wat is je adres?

content.text: Let's go shopping! In this lesson, you'll learn the essential Dutch phrases for a successful trip to 'de supermarkt'.

content.title: Articles: Definite vs. Indefinite
content.explanation: You've learned 'de' and 'het' (the). The indefinite article 'a' or 'an' is 'een' for all nouns. Example: 'de appel' (the apple), 'een appel' (an apple).

content.text: Adding 'graag' makes a request more polite, similar to 'would like' instead of 'want'.

content.title: Modal Verb: willen (to want)
content.explanation: 'Willen' is used to express a desire. The second verb goes to the end of the sentence. Conjugation: ik wil, jij wilt, u wilt.

data.tip: The Dutch 'g' sound is made in the back of your throat. The 'aa' is a long 'ah' sound.

content.title: Question Pattern: Waar...?
content.explanation: To ask 'where', you start with 'Waar'. The verb comes second. For example: 'Waar vind ik de melk?'

content.title: Countable vs. Uncountable
content.explanation: Some nouns are countable ('een appel', 'twee appels'), others are uncountable ('melk', 'kaas'). Uncountable nouns use different quantifiers.

content.text: For uncountable items like cheese, you can ask for a quantity like 'een kilo kaas' or just 'wat kaas' (some cheese).

content.title: Finding Items
content.setting: You're in a Dutch supermarket and need help finding a few things. You see an employee you can ask.

user_goal.title: Ask the employee where you can find the cheese.
user_goal.prompt: Goedemorgen! Kan ik u helpen?

user_goal.title: Say you would like a kilo of cheese.
user_goal.prompt: De kaas is daar. Anders nog iets?

extract_info.item_name: Extract the item the user wants (cheese).

user_goal.title: Ask how much the cheese costs.
user_goal.prompt: Oké, een kilo {item_name}. Dat kan.

data.tip: Stress the second syllable. The 'h' is pronounced softly, and the 'v' sounds like an 'f'.

content.title: Modal Verb: kunnen (can)
content.explanation: 'Kunnen' expresses ability. The second verb goes to the end. Conjugation: ik kan, jij kunt, u kunt.

data.meaning: Can I pay with a debit card?

content.text: 'Pinnen' is a very common verb in the Netherlands that specifically means to pay with a debit card using a PIN code.

data.meaning: I'd like to pay by card, please.

content.text: Remember to bring your own shopping bag ('tas') or you will have to buy one at the checkout.

content.title: At the Checkout
content.setting: You have your items (a bottle of water and an apple) and you are at the checkout ('kassa'). The cashier tells you the total.

user_goal.title: Say that you want to pay by debit card.
user_goal.prompt: Hallo. Dat is dan drie euro, alstublieft.

user_goal.title: Answer 'yes' to the cashier's question.
user_goal.prompt: Oké. Wilt u de kassabon?

user_goal.title: Thank the cashier.
user_goal.prompt: Alstublieft. Fijne dag!

content.text: Welkom! Let's learn how to order food and drinks in a Dutch café or restaurant. Eet smakelijk! (Enjoy your meal!)

content.title: Polite Requests: Mag ik...?
content.explanation: 'Mag ik...?' is a very polite way to ask for something, translating to 'May I have...?'. It's more common than 'Kan ik hebben?'.

content.text: 'Ik neem...' is a decisive way to order, similar to saying 'I'll take...' or 'I'll have...'.

content.title: Using 'graag'
content.explanation: Adding 'graag' to your order makes it more polite. For example: 'Ik wil graag een koffie' (I would like a coffee).

data.tip: The 'g' sound comes from the back of the throat. The 'aa' is a long 'ah' sound.

content.text: 'Lekker' is a very common word used to describe food and drinks you enjoy.

content.title: Ordering a Drink
content.setting: You've just sat down at a café terrace. The waiter comes to take your order.

user_goal.title: Politely ask for the menu.
user_goal.prompt: Goedemiddag! Wat kan ik voor u doen?

user_goal.title: Order a coffee.
user_goal.prompt: Alstublieft, hier is de kaart. Wat wilt u drinken?

user_goal.title: Say that it was tasty.
user_goal.prompt: Oké, een koffie. Komt eraan! ... Alstublieft. Is de koffie lekker?

content.title: Adjectives: The -e Ending
content.explanation: When an adjective comes before a noun with 'de' or 'het', it usually gets an '-e' at the end. For example: 'groot' becomes 'de grote tafel'.

data.phrase: Ik wil graag een kleine koffie.
data.meaning: I would like a small coffee.

data.tip: The '-tje' ending makes a word diminutive ('little bread'). It's pronounced as a soft 'ch-yuh'.

content.title: Negation: 'geen'
content.explanation: Use 'geen' to negate a noun that has an indefinite article ('een') or no article. It means 'no' or 'not a'.

content.title: Negation: 'niet'
content.explanation: Use 'niet' ('not') to negate everything else: verbs, adjectives, adverbs, and nouns with a definite article ('de' or 'het').

data.tip: The stress is on the first syllable. The 'g' at the end is very soft.

content.text: In the Netherlands, the service charge is included in the price. Tipping is not required, but rounding up the bill for good service is appreciated.

content.title: Ordering Food and Paying
content.setting: You are ready to order your meal and later ask for the bill.

user_goal.title: Say you will have the soup.
user_goal.prompt: Prima. En wat wilt u eten?

user_goal.title: Say no, you don't want bread.
user_goal.prompt: Goede keuze. Wilt u een broodje bij de soep?

user_goal.title: Say that it's delicious.
user_goal.prompt: Oké, geen broodje. [A few minutes later] Alstublieft, hier is uw soep. Is het lekker?

user_goal.title: Ask for the bill, please.
user_goal.prompt: Fijn om te horen! Kan ik nog iets voor u doen?

content.text: Welkom! In this lesson, we'll learn how to tell time, talk about the calendar, and make appointments ('afspraken').

data.tip: The 'aa' is a long, open 'ah' sound, like in the English word 'father'.

content.title: Preposition 'om'
content.explanation: To specify a time, you use the preposition 'om'. For example: 'om twee uur' (at two o'clock).

data.tip: The 'w' is soft, like a 'v'. The 'g' at the end is a soft, breathy sound.

content.title: Preposition 'op'
content.explanation: To specify a day, you use the preposition 'op'. For example: 'op maandag' (on Monday).

content.title: Making a Plan
content.setting: You want to make an appointment with your friend, Chris. You start the conversation.

user_goal.title: Ask when he is available.
user_goal.prompt: Hallo! Ik wil graag een afspraak maken.

user_goal.title: Suggest Monday at two o'clock.
user_goal.prompt: Ik kan op maandag of op dinsdag. Wat is goed voor jou?

user_goal.title: Confirm that it's a deal.
user_goal.prompt: Maandag om twee uur is perfect voor mij.

content.title: Future with 'gaan'
content.explanation: To talk about future plans, you can use the verb 'gaan' (to go). The second verb goes to the end of the sentence. Example: 'Ik ga op vrijdag werken.'

data.meaning: I am going to work on Wednesday.

content.text: Unlike in English, the names of days and months are not capitalized in Dutch unless they start a sentence.

content.title: Dates
content.explanation: To say the date, you use the number followed by the month. Example: 'Het is 3 april' (It is April 3rd).

content.title: Preposition 'in'
content.explanation: Use the preposition 'in' for months and years. For example: 'in maart' (in March).

content.title: Numbers: 100 and 1000
content.explanation: 100 is 'honderd'. 1000 is 'duizend'. For example, 200 is 'tweehonderd'.

data.tip: The 'ui' sound is tricky. Start by saying 'ow' as in 'cow', but with rounded lips.

content.title: Preposition 'van ... tot ...'
content.explanation: To indicate a period of time, use 'van ... tot ...' (from ... to ...). Example: 'van negen uur tot tien uur'.

content.text: 'Tot' means 'until', so 'Tot dan!' literally means 'Until then!'. You can also say 'Tot maandag!' (See you Monday!).

content.title: Scheduling a Meeting
content.setting: You are on the phone with a colleague to schedule a meeting for next week.

user_goal.title: Ask if Wednesday at ten o'clock works for them.
user_goal.prompt: Goedemorgen. Ik bel om een vergadering te plannen. Wanneer kun je?

user_goal.title: Say you are going to work from nine to five.
user_goal.prompt: Nee, woensdag om tien uur kan ik niet. En op donderdag?

extract_info.day_of_week: Extract the day the user suggests for the meeting.

user_goal.title: Confirm that Thursday from 10 to 11 is good and say 'See you then!'.
user_goal.prompt: Oké, {day_of_week} kan ik. Past het van tien tot elf?

content.text: Welkom! This lesson will help you navigate Dutch public transport ('openbaar vervoer'). Let's learn how to get around by bus, tram, or train.

data.tip: The '-tje' suffix makes the word smaller ('little card'). It is pronounced like 'ch-yuh'.

content.title: Modal Verb: kunnen (can/be able)
content.explanation: Use 'kunnen' to ask about possibilities. Conjugation: ik kan, jij/u kunt, hij/zij kan.

content.title: Yes/No Questions
content.explanation: Remember, to ask a yes/no question, you start with the verb. Example: 'Deze bus gaat naar het centrum.' becomes 'Gaat deze bus naar het centrum?'

content.text: The 'OV-chipkaart' is a rechargeable card used for all public transport in the Netherlands. You can also buy single-use tickets.

content.title: Buying a Ticket
content.setting: You are at the ticket counter of a train station and want to buy a ticket to the city center.

user_goal.title: Ask for a one-way ticket to the center.
user_goal.prompt: Goedendag, waarmee kan ik u helpen?

user_goal.title: Say yes, you want to pay by card.
user_goal.prompt: Oké, een enkele reis naar het centrum. Dat is vier euro. Wilt u pinnen?

user_goal.title: Say thank you.
user_goal.prompt: Prima. Hier is uw kaartje naar {destination}. Goede reis!

content.title: Imperatives
content.explanation: To give a command or instruction, you use the verb stem (the 'ik' form). For example, the verb 'nemen' (to take) becomes 'Neem'.

data.phrase: Stap uit bij de volgende halte.
data.meaning: Get off at the next stop.

data.tip: The stress is on the first part, 'uit'. The 'ui' sound is like 'ou' in 'loud'.

data.meaning: Where do I have to transfer?

content.title: Modal Verb: moeten (must/have to)
content.explanation: 'Moeten' expresses necessity. Conjugation: ik moet, jij/u moet, hij/zij moet.

content.title: Modal Verb: mogen (may/be allowed to)
content.explanation: 'Mogen' is used to ask for permission. Conjugation: ik mag, jij/u mag, hij/zij mag.

content.text: In Dutch buses and trams, you must check in ('inchecken') when you get on and check out ('uitchecken') when you get off.

data.meaning: It is on the left side.

content.title: Asking for the Right Stop
content.setting: You are on a tram and want to make sure you get off at the right stop for the museum. You decide to ask the driver.

user_goal.title: Ask if this tram goes to the museum.
user_goal.prompt: Goedemorgen. Kan ik u helpen?

user_goal.title: Ask where you have to get off.
user_goal.prompt: Jazeker. Deze tram stopt bij het museum.

user_goal.title: Ask if that is the next stop.
user_goal.prompt: U moet bij de halte 'Museumplein' uitstappen.

user_goal.title: Thank the driver.
user_goal.prompt: Ja, dat is de volgende halte. U moet hier uitstappen.
